official-title.#text: To amend title 38, United States Code, to establish a presumption of service connection for certain veterans with tinnitus or hearing loss.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text: Reducing Barriers to Veterans’ Benefits Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

text.#text: Tinnitus is the most common service-connected disability for veterans from all periods of service, accounting for almost 841,000 individuals.
Hearing loss is the second leading service-connected disability for veterans from all periods of service, accounting for almost 702,000 individuals.
Since fiscal year 1999, the number of veterans with service-connected disability for tinnitus has increased by an average rate of 17 percent each year.
The number of tinnitus disabilities has grown from 128,600 in fiscal year 1999 to 840,900 in fiscal year 2011, an increase of more than 500 percent.

header.#text: Presumption of service-connection for hearing loss and tinnitus

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , is amended by adding at the end the following new section:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Subchapter II of chapter 11 of title 38, United States Code

header.#text: Presumption of service connection for hearing loss associated with particular military occupational specialties or combat service

shall be considered to have been incurred in or aggravated by the service of the veteran, notwithstanding that there is no record of evidence of such hearing loss or tinnitus, as the case may be, during the period of such service.
